metadata.title: Title: Nitrogen and phosphorus co-doped graphene quantum dots as a nano-sensor for highly sensitive and selective imaging detection of nitrite in live cell

sections.text:
Accepted Manuscript
Title: Nitrogen and phosphorus co-doped graphene quantum dots as a nano-sensor for highly sensitive and selective imaging detection of nitrite in live cell Author: Rongjun Liu Jingjin Zhao Zirong Huang Liangliang Zhang Mengbing Zou Bingfang Shi Shulin Zhao PII: S0925-4005(16)31425-3 DOI: http://dx.doi.org/doi:10.1016/j.snb.2016.09.008 Reference: SNB 20873 To appear in: Sensors and Actuators B Received date: 5-7-2016 Revised date: 30-8-2016 Accepted date: 3-9-2016 Please cite this article as: Rongjun Liu, Jingjin Zhao, Zirong Huang, Liangliang Zhang, Mengbing Zou, Bingfang Shi, Shulin Zhao, Nitrogen and phosphorus codoped graphene quantum dots as a nano-sensor for highly sensitive and selective imaging detection of nitrite in live cell, Sensors and Actuators B: Chemical http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.snb.2016.09.008 This is a PDF file of an unedited manuscript that has been accepted for publication. As a service to our customers we are providing this early version of the manuscript. The manuscript will undergo copyediting, typesetting, and review of the resulting proof before it is published in its final form. Please note that during the production process errors may be discovered which could affect the content, and all legal disclaimers that apply to the journal pertain.
Nitrogen and phosphorus co-doped graphene quantum dots as a nano-sensor for highly sensitive and selective imaging detection of nitrite in live cell

sections.heading: Rongjun Liu,a,b Jingjin Zhao,a* Zirong Huang,a Liangliang Zhang,a Mengbing Zou,a
sections.text:
Bingfang Shi,a Shulin Zhaoa*
a State Key Laboratory for the Chemistry and Molecular Engineering of Medicinal
Resources, Guangxi Normal University, Guilin, 541004, China
b Guangxi Key Laboratory for Agricultural Resources Chemistry and Efficient
Utilization, Yulin Normal University, Yulin, 537000, China.
*Corresponding author: Tel: +86 773 2120226, Fax: +86 773 5832294,
E-mail: zhaoshulin001@163.com; E-mail: jzhao12@163.com

sections.heading: Research Highlights
sections.text:
1. A novel graphene quantum dots is prepared by doping nitrogen and phosphorus.
2. A new fluorescence probe was developed for the detection of nitrite.
3. The assay is high sensitivity and selectivity for imaging detection of nitrite in live cell.

sections.heading: ABSTRACT
sections.text:
Doping graphene quantum dots (GQDs) with heteroatoms can provide new or improved structural and optical properties. Therefore, heteroatom doped GQDs have promising applications in environmental and biological fields. In this work, we present a novel nitrogen and phosphorus co-doped graphene quantum dots (N,P-GQDs), which were directly prepared via a facile hydrothermal method using tetrakis (hydroxymethyl) phosphonium chloride and ethylenediamine endcapped polyethylenimine as precursors. N,P-GQDs with two different doping ratios of nitrogen and phosphorus were prepared at different temperatures (230 and 250°C). This N,P-GQDs showed good dispersity, thickness of 1–3 atomic layers and sizes of less than 20 nm. The N,P-GQDs were water dispersible, highly luminescent (with an absolute quantum yield of 9.4%), and showed excitation and concentration-dependent behavior. Moreover, the N,P-GQDs exhibited a sensitive response to NO2 - in the concentration range of 5−30 nM with the detection limit of 2.5 nM. Significantly, cell toxicity experiment showed that the N,P-GQDs had negligible cytotoxicity and excellent biocompatibility. Thus, the N,P-GQDs could serve as a powerful fluorescent nano-sensor for imaging detection of nitrite in live cell.
Keywords: Doped graphene quantum dots; Nitrogen; Phosphorus; Detection of nitrite; Live cell imaging

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
In recent years, photoluminescent carbon dots (C-dots) or graphene quantum dots (GQDs) have attracted increasing attention owing to their chemical inertness, low cytotoxicity, excellent biocompatibility, good dispersibility in water, and stable photoluminescence (PL). This makes them most promising fluorescent nanomaterials [1-4]. However, the photoluminescence quantum yields of GQDs are extremely low, ranging from 1–5%, indicating that pristine GQDs have a high density of defect states [5,6]. Fortunately, later studies have shown that the quantum yields of GQDs can be improved by using heteroatom doping, such as nitrogen [7], boron [8], sulfur [9], phosphorus [10], and fluorin [11]. Doping with different heteroatoms may induce some changes in GQDs composition, morphology and structure, presenting distinctive properties. Notably, the Lee’s group has synthesized near-infrared photoluminescent graphene quantum dots with zigzag edges by using strong acid treatment and nitrogen doping [12]. Dong et al. reported the synthesis of nitrogen and sulfur co-doped carbon-based dots (N,S-CDs) with a high photoluminescence quantum yield (73%) through a one-step hydrothermal treatment [13]. On the other hand, heteroatom doping can also change the sensitivity of GQDs to their environment. Thus, doped GQDs can be used as an ultrasensitive fluorescent probe for the detection of different analytes, such as Fe3+ [14], Ag+ [15], chloramphenicol (CAP) [16], and 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP) [17].
Nitrite (NO2 -) is an important inorganic anion that is usually used as a food additive or a preservative agent [18]. However, it is also considered to be a cancerogen owing
to its ability to interact with amines and proteins to generate highly carcinogenic N-nitrosamines, which enhance the possibility of cancer and deformities [19]. Contamination of rural drinking water supplies with nitrite by livestock waste, organic wastes, and chemical fertilizers continues to be a problem throughout the world [20]. In addition, nitrite is also an important metabolite in many physiological and pathological processes [19]. Monitoring nitrite in living cells is of great benefit to understand the mechanism of cell apoptosis. Therefore, the rapid, low-cost, and sensitive detection of nitrite ion is of great importance in environmental and biological systems. Previously reported methods for the detection of nitrite include ion selective electrode [21], chemiluminescence [22], and electrochemical techniques [23]. However, these methods usually involve complicated or time-consuming processes, expensive equipment, and high costs, whereas fluorescence analysis is currently considered to be a highly effective method of nitrite detection. So far, only a few fluorescent probes such as organic probe [24], Cu nanoclusters [25], dimer [26], and carbon nanoparticles [27] have been reported to determine the nitrite. Notably, detection of nitrite in live cell is still challenging due to the lack of highly selective, highly sensitive, simple and rapid methods. Thus, synthesis of highly selective and sensitive fluorescent nano-sensor for imaging detection of nitrite in live cell is expectant.
In this work, a novel nitrogen and phosphorus co-doped GQDs (N,P-GQDs)
were synthesized through a hydrothermal carbonization method by using tetrakis(hydroxymethyl) phosphonium chloride (THPC) and ethylenediamine
endcapped polyethylenimine (PEI-EC) as precursors (Fig.1a). THPC served as the carbon and phosphorus source, while the PEI-EC with NH2 groups provided nitrogen source and as a passivation agent. The obtained N,P-GQDs had sizes of less than 20 nm and not only exhibited high crystallinity with thickness of 0.36–0.65 nm, and lower cytotoxicity, but also presented superior optical properties, such as strong PL, tunable full-color emission, and high photo-stability. Thus, the N,P-GQDs were highly suitable for live cell labeling and imaging. Furthermore, we demonstrated that the N,P-GQDs can be utilized as fluorescent nano-sensor for imaging detection of nitrite in live cell.

sections.heading: 2.1 Reagents and materials
sections.text:
THPC and PEI-EC were purchased from Sigma Aldrich. Other chemicals are analytically pure and used as received without further purification. Water was purified by employing a Milli-Q plus 185 equip from Millipore (Bedford, MA) and used throughout the work.. 2.2 Synthesis of N,P-GQDs
A mixed solution was prepared by dissolving 1.5 ml of THPC and 500 µL of PEI-EC in 25 mL of water. Then, the mixed solution was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon equipped stainless steel autoclave and placed in a drying oven at 230°C or 250°C for 8 h. After cooling to room temperature, the yellow liquid (acidic solution) was adjusted to 7.0 by adding NaOH solution under stirring. The obtained mixture
was dialyzed in a dialysis bag for 24 h (molecular-weight cutoff of 1000) to remove small molecular substances. Then the obtained N,P-GQD was preserved for further characterization and use. 2.3 Characterization of N,P-GQDs
The UV-vis absorption spectra of N,P-GQDs were recorded on a Cary 60 UV-vis spectrophotometer (Agilent Technologies, Australia). All fluorescence spectra were obtained on a Cary Eclipse fluorescence spectrometer (Agilent Technologies, Australia). Fluorescence lifetime experiments were performed by a FL3-P-TCSPC time-resolved fluorescence spectrometer (Horiba Jobin Jvon). The absolute quantum yields were measured on FLS980 Edinburgh Fluorescence Spectrometer (Edinburgh, UK) with an integrating sphere. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images of N,P-GQDs were operated at a voltage of 300 kV on an FEI Tecnai G2 F-30 field emission HRTEM (Holand). Atomic force microscopy (AFM) images were obtained by a Multimode Nanoscope IIIa controllor AFM (USA). The X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of N,P-GQDs was measured using a diffractometer (Rigaku D/max 2500, Japan) with Cu Ka radiation. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) datas were obtained with a Thermo ESCALAB 250XI electron spectrometer from VG Scientific using 150 W Al Ka radiation. FT-IR spectrum of the N,P-GQDs was recorded on FT-IR (PerkinElmer, USA) spectrometer. The Raman spectra of N,P-GQDs were measured on Laser Micro-Raman spectrometer (Invia, Renishaw, England). 2.4 Detection of NO2 -
A 20 µL volume of the N,P-GQDs solution was mixed with 60 µL Tris-HCl buffer solution (10 mM pH 7.0). After that, 20 µL of different concentrations of nitrite solution was added with gentle shaking. The fluorescence spectra were recorded 20 min later within the wavelength range of 360 nm to 600 nm at 350 nm excitation. 2.5 MTT Assay
Human bladder carcinoma T24 cells were harvested (the cell density was adjusted to 105 cells per mL) and seeded in a 96-well plate overnight for 24 h. Then, the N,P-GQDs solution was added into each well with increasing concentrations from 20 to100 μg/mL. After that, the cells were cultivated for 24 h, and 10 μL of 1 mg/mL MTT (3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyltetra- zolium bromide) solution was added to each cell well. After incubation for 4 h, the culture medium was discarded, and 100 μL of dimethyl sulfoxide was added. The obtained mixture was shaken for 15 min in the dark at room temperature, and the absorbance of each well was measured at 570 nm using an enzyme linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) reader with pure DMSO as a blank. A non-treated cell was used as a control and the relative cell viability (mean% ± SD, n=3) was expressed as Abssample/Abscontrol 100%. 2.6 Live cell imaging
Human bladder carcinoma T24 cells were maintained in Dulbecco’s modified eagle medium (DMEM) supplemented with FBS (10%) and 100 mg/mL streptomycin and 100 units/mL penicillin solution in 5% CO2 at 37°C. Cells were grown on the bottom of 35 mm glass culture dishes to the density of 70% confluence and then incubated with N,P-GQDs at 37°C for 20 h. Afterwards, the cells were washed three times with
PBS (pH 7.4). Images of the cells were immediately captured at ambient temperature on a laser scanning confocal microscopy (Zeiss LSM710, Germany) using a digital camera.

sections.heading: 3.1 Characterization of the N,P-GQDs
sections.text:
The N,P-GQDs230°C and the N,P-GQDs250°C, which were respectively heated at a reaction temperature of 230 °C and 250 °C, were synthesized via hydrothermal method. The morphology and structure of the as-prepared N,P-GQDs were characterized using transmission electron microscopy (TEM), high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), and atomic force microscopy (AFM). Fig. 1b shows the TEM image of the N,P-GQDs230°C, which is well-dispersed in water with a size distribution in 1.5–7.5 nm range and an average size of 4.2 nm (shown in the inset). Fig. 1c is the inverse fast Fourier transform (IFFT) HRTEM image from Fig. S1a, and the inset shows the 2D Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) pattern of the N,P-GQDs230°C. The HRTEM image (Fig. 1c) depicts the high crystallinity of the N,P-GQDs230°C, with a hexagonal graphene network, zigzag edges and size of ca. 7 nm. The result is consistent with that zigzag-edge GQDs had 7–8 nm average dimensions reported by Ritter et al [28]. The hexagonal lattice observed in the 2D FFT image reveals that the N,P-GQDs230°C consisted of crystalline hexagonal structures. The thickness of the N,P-GQDs230°C was evaluated by AFM. Fig. 1d shows a height of 0.652 nm. Using a theoretical thickness of a graphene monolayer of 0.34
nm, the AFM data imply that the N,P-GQDs230°C consisted of 1-3 layers of graphene sheets, and that they were GQDs instead of spherical carbon nanocrystals. Other HRTEM images of the N,P-GQDs230°C are shown in Fig. S1. Fig. 2 shows HRTEM images and corresponding 2D FFT patterns of the N,P-GQDs250°C. The N,P-GQDs250°C was larger in size, at ca. 20 nm (Fig. 2e). Interestingly, previously reported hexagonal lattices from 2D FFT images of graphene and undoped GQDs were orthohexagonal [29-32]. However, in our as-prepared N,P-GQDs, the hexagonal lattice in the 2D FFT images (Fig. 1c and Fig. 2b) was non-orthohexagonal, suggesting that the N,P-GQDs contained a certain number of imperfections of the crytal lattice [33]. This may be due to the perfect orthohexagonal graphene network of the GQDs being altered by N, P atoms co-doping [34]. Furthermore, HRTEM images and 2D FFT analysis indicate that the N,P-GQDs250°C were more crystalline than the N,P-GQDs230°C. TEM and AFM images of the N,P-GQDs250°C are shown in Fig. S2 and Fig. S3, respectively. These images show that the N,P-GQDs250°C were highly dispersed in water and had a single- or few-layered graphite-like structure.
The elemental compositions and contents of the N,P-GQDs were further confirmed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The XPS survey spectra of the N,P-GQDs (Fig. 3) show that they possessed four peaks corresponding to carbon, oxygen, nitrogen, and phosphorus. Elemental analysis indicates an increase in the carbon content of the N,P-GQDs250°C, with an associated decrease in oxygen, nitrogen, and phosphorus levels (73.52% C1s, 16.50% O1s, 2.95% N1s, and 7.03% P2p) compared to the N,P-GQDs230°C (41.79% C1s, 43.65% O1s, 5.85% N1s, 8.71% P2p).
These results suggest that the oxygen-rich N,P-GQDs230°C possessed a higher doping ratio of N and P compared to the carbon-rich N,P-GQDs250°C, which underwent further carbonization [35]. High resolution XPS spectra of C1s (b), N1s (c), and P2p (d) for the N,P-GQDs230°C and the N,P-GQDs250°C are shown in Fig. S4 and S5, respectively. Furthermore, the XRD pattern of the N,P-GQDs is shown in Fig. S6. The diffraction peaks at 2θ = 24.1° and 43.1° are associated with the (002), and (100) planes of the graphite-like structure of the N,P-GQDs. The extent of disorder or the degree of crystallinity in doped GQDs was investigated by Raman spectroscopy [36]. As shown in Fig. S7, the two N,P-GQDs samples both exhibited three characteristic bands appearing at approximately 1350 cm-1 (D-band), 1600 cm-1 (G-band), and 2750 cm-1 (2D-band). It is notable that a strong peak at 1390 cm-1 was observed in the N,P-GQDs230°C sample, which may be attributed to the C-P and C-N bonds. The G-band of the N,P-GQDs250°C was red-shifted 25 cm -1 relative to the G-band of graphene (1580 cm-1) [37], suggesting that the changes in the N,P-GQDs250°C were related to doping with foreign species (N and P). In addition, the intensity ratio (ID/IG) was found to decrease from 0.92 for the N,P-GQDs230°C to 0.86 for the N,P-GQDs250°C, suggesting that the latter had a higher degree of crystallinity. This indicates that the N,P-GQDs250°C had lower ratios of N and P doping than the N,P-GQDs230°C. This result is consistent with the HRTEM images and XPS analysis, and further confirms that N and P were successfully doped into the N,P-GQDs. 3.2 Optical properties of the N,P-GQDs
The optical properties of the N,P-GQDs were investigated using ultraviolet-visible
(UV-vis) spectroscopy, PL spectroscopy, and PL excitation measurements. The UV-vis absorption spectrum of the N,P-GQDs230°C in water shows two clear absorption peaks at 275 nm and 350 nm (Fig. 4a). The weak peak at 275 nm was related to the π-π* transitions in the carbon core of the aromatic π-bonded system [38]. The prominent peak at 350 nm was due to the n-π* transition of the C=O, C=P, and C=N bonds [39]. Similarly, two peaks at 357 nm and 240 nm were observed in the PL excitation spectrum of the N,P-GQDs230°C (Fig. 4a) that can be attributed to the σ-π and π-π* transitions. Under irradiation with a 365 nm UV lamp, the N,P-GQDs230°C showed strong blue luminescence (inset of Fig. 4a). Form Fig. S8, the absolute quantum yield was calculated to be 9.4% using the absolute method as previously reported [40], which is much higher than that of undoping GQDs [41]. The UV-vis absorption spectrum of the N,P-GQDs250°C is shown in Fig. S9a. The prominent peak at 275 nm is attributed to C=C π-π* transitions. Compared with the UV-vis absorption spectrum of the N,P-GQDs230°C (Fig. 4a), the N,P-GQDs250°C absorption peak at 355 nm was very weak, indicating a small amount of N and P atoms were doped onto the N,P-GQDs250°C. This result is consistent with those from the HRTEM images, XPS, and Raman spectroscopy. Moreover, the synthesized N,P-GQDs250°C not only exhibited excitation-independent full-color emission characteristics with a maximum emission of 650 nm when excited at 620 nm (Fig. 4b), but also show concentration-dependent luminescence behavior with an increase in the concentration from 0.05 mg/mL to 0.45 mg/mL resulting in a red-shift in the maximum excitation wavelength from 360 nm to 480 nm (Fig. S10, Fig. 4b). At the same concentrations
(0.30 mg/mL), PL emission of the N,P-GQDs250°C was red-shifted compared to the N,P-GQDs230°C (Fig. S9b and Fig. S10a), which may be due to the decreased band gap of the N,P-GQDs250°C and the consequent reduction in N, P and O levels [42,43]. 3.3. Stability of the N,P-GQDs
The N,P-GQDs230°C exhibited excellent aqueous dispersibility due to the presence of hydrophilic groups such as –OH and –NH2 on their surfaces (see FT-IR spectrum in Fig. S11). The N,P-GQDs230°C exhibited also excellent photostability, and approximately 70% of initial fluorescence intensity was obtained after UV irradiation for 70 h (Fig. S12). The stability of N,P-GQDs230°C under high ion strength was investigated in the presence of different concentrations of NaCl. As can be seen in Fig. S13, the change fluorescence intensity of N,P-GQDs230°C was slight in the presence of 2.0 M NaCl, indicating the high stability of N,P-GQDs230°C under a high ion strength ambient condition. The fluorescence test of the N,P-CDs230°C under different pH solutions indicate that the fluorescence of the N,P-CDs230°C is basically stable and strong in a wide range of pH values from 1 to 8 (Fig. S14). 3.4 Sensing of NO2 - using N,P-GQDs
The fluorescence quenching of the N,P-GQDs by NO2 - is pH-sensitive, and the best response was obtained at pH 7.0 (Fig. S15). The sensitivity and linear response range of the N,P-GQDs-based sensing system were evaluated by monitoring the fluorescence intensity of the N,P-GQDs230°C upon addition of NO2 - under optimal pH conditions. As shown in Fig. 6a, the value of the fluorescence intensity at 470 nm decreased gradually with increasing NO2 - concentration. When the concentration of

sections.heading: NO2
sections.text:
- was 0.8 μM, the fluorescence intensity had been quenched to approximately 70% of its initial value. Fig. 6b shows the relationship between the fluorescence quenching efficiency of the N,P-GQDs230°C and the NO2 - concentration. The inset of Fig. 6b shows the linear correlation (R2=0.9960) on the concentration of NO2 - in the range of 5–30 nM with the linear regression equation I0/I=0.0423 [NO2 -]+0.8149. The detection limit was estimated to be 2.5 nM with a signal-to-noise ratio of 3, which is lower than some other methods for the detection of NO2 - [44-46]. To further investigate the fluorescence “turn-off” mechanism, fluorescence lifetime spectroscopy was used to study the exciton behavior of the N,P-GQDs230°C in the presence and absence of NO2 - (Fig. S16). The fluorescence lifetimes were calculated and shown in Table S1. The lifetime of the N,P-GQDs230°C was 6.57 ns and consisted of two components: 2.2 ns (ca. 20.6%) and 7.7 ns (ca. 79.4%). After treatment with NO2 -, the lifetime of the N,P-GQDs230°C decreased to 5.15 ns, and consisted of two components: 7.3 ns (ca. 62.9%) and 1.5 ns (ca. 37.1%). The shorter lifetime revealed a dynamic quenching mechanism after the introduction of NO2 - to the N,P-GQDs230°C solution. Moreover, UV–vis absorption spectra were used to insight into the mechanism of quenching. As shown in Fig. S17, the absorption peak of the N,P-GQDs230°C slightly shifted to a shorter wavelength in the presence of NO2 -, which suggests that this shift is attributable to the formation of some complexes owing to the strong chemical interreaction of NO2 - to -NH2 on the surface of N,P-GQDs230°C. A surface modifier onto the semiconductor surface may induce the lifetime of semiconductor colloids decreases [47]. Based on the fluorescence lifetime data mentioned above, we suggest
that the sensing mechanism should be a dynamic quenching. When NO2 - is added into N,P-GQDs solution, the stronger interreaction of NO2 - with -NH2 on the surface of N,P-GQDs230°C result in electron transfer from the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) levels of N,P-GQDs to the of NO2 -, which lead to fluorescence quenching [48]. 3.5 Specificity of the sensing system The specificity of the sensing system for NO2 - was evaluated before its application in a real sample. The changes of the fluorescence intensity of the N,P-GQDs230°C in the presence of glutathione (GSH), hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) and various ions including SO4 2-, Cl-, NO3 -, Ac-, PO4 3-, HCO3 -, CO3 2-, Br-, F-, S2- , NO2 -, K+, Na+, Ca2+and Mg2+ were examined. As can be seen in Fig. 5, GSH, H2O2 and various ions at a concentration of 10 μM showed a minor influence on the fluorescence intensity of the N,P-GQDs230°C with the exception of NO2 - which noticeably quenched the fluorescence of the N,P-GQDs230°C. This result indicates that the N,P-GQDs230°C can be used as a fluorescence probe for highly selective sensing of NO2 -. Furthermore, the quenched fluorescence intensity of the N,P-GQDs230°C by NO2 - was stronger than N,P-GQDs250°C. A plausible reason for this phenomenon could be that the oxygen-rich N,P-GQDs230°C with a higher doping ratio of N and P contained more active sites [3], which can interact powerfully with NO2 - to strengthen nonradiative electron transfer. 3.6 Application of N,P-GQDs in live cell imaging
Before the N,P-GQDs were used as fluorescent bioprobes for live cell imaging, the cytotoxicity of the N,P-GQDs was tested by using standard MTT assay. As shown
in Fig. S18, over 90% cell viability was observed after incubating T24 cells with the N,P-GQDs (20–100 μg/mL) for 24 h. Thus, the as-prepared N,P-GQDs can act as good fluorescent bioprobes for live cell imaging. Changes in the fluorescence color of the N,P-GQDs250°C were measured in live T24 cells using confocal fluorescence microscopy with different excitation wavelengths. As shown in Fig. 7, the N,P-GQDs250°C showed blue, green, and red emission when excited at wavelengths of 405, 488, and 535 nm, respectively. This result was in agreement with the excitation-independent full-color emission character of the N,P-GQDs250°C (Fig. 4b). These images also showed that the N,P-GQDs250°C were mainly observed in the cell cytoplasm. Moreover, from Fig. 7e, green fluorescence of N,P-GQDs250°C were observed in the cell membranes when excited at wavelength of 488 nm. The phenomenon possibly arise from the bigger size of N,P-GQDs250°C (see Fig. 2e) that has weaker fluorescence and fluorescence signal which can’t be observed under 405 and 535 nm excitation (Fig. 7a and 7c). Therefore, we suggest a size-selective permeability on cell membranes, most of N,P-GQDs250°C with small size might allow their through cell membranes and enter cells. 3.7 Imaging detection of nitrite in live cell
N,P-GQDs230°C were observed in cell cytoplasm rather than in the cell membrane in live cell imaging, and the quenched fluorescence intensity of the N,P-GQDs230°C by NO2 - was stronger than N,P-GQDs250°C. Therefore, the N,P-GQDs230°C were used as fluorescent nano-sensor for imaging detection of nitrite in live cell. As shown in Fig. 8, weak fluorescence was detected in the T24 cells when they were incubated with 10
nM of NO2 - for another 0.5 h (Fig. 8b). Weaker fluorescence was detected in the T24 cells when the NO2 - concentration reached 20 nM (Fig. 8c). When the NO2 - concentration reached 30 nM, no fluorescence was detected in the T24 cells (Fig. 8d). These results demonstrate that the N,P-GQDs230°C can be used for intracellular imaging detection of NO2 - at nanomolar levels in live cells.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: In summary, we have developed a facile and universal bottom-up process for the fabrication of N,P-GQDs. The chemical structure and optical properties of the N,P-GQDs were investigated in detail. Our results showed that the N and P were successfully doped into the GQDs, which possessed excellent aqueous dispersibility, strong PL, continuous full-color emission, good photo-stability. Furthermore, the N,P-GQDs can be utilized as a fluorescent nano-sensor for highly sensitive and selective detecting NO2 - in environmental and bio-systems. Notably, cellular experiments showed the N,P-GQDs had limited cytotoxicity and were biocompatible. Thus, the N,P-GQDs can be used as an eco-friendly nano-sensor for imaging detection of NO2 - in live cell. We believe that the N,P-GQDs may be promising in vivo imaging, and biomedicine applications.

sections.heading: Appendix A. Supplementary data
sections.text:
Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version,
at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.snb.2016.xxxx.

sections.heading: Biographies
sections.text:
Rongjun Liu is an experimentalist in Yulin Normal University and currently working toward the Ph.D. degree at the College of Chemistry and Pharmacy of Guangxi Normal University, China. He received his master degree from Guangxi Normal University in 2010. His research interests are synthesis of nanomaterials, fluorescent sensor and biological imaging.
Jingjin Zhao received both her M.S. and Ph.D. degree in Analytical Chemistry from University of Hunan in 2009 and 2012, respectively. Now, she works in Guangxi Normal University and majors in chemical and biological sensing technology.
Zirong Huang is currently working toward the bachelor degree at the College of Chemistry and Pharmacy of Guangxi Normal University, China. Her research interests focus on biological imaging.
Liangliang Zhang received both his M.S. and Ph.D. degrees in Analytical Chemistry from Hunan University in 2009 and 2012, respectively. Now, he works in Guangxi Normal University and majors in chemical and biological sensing technology.
Mengbing Zou is currently working toward the bachelor degree at the College of Chemistry and Pharmacy of Guangxi Normal University, China. Her research interests focus on functional nanomaterials and chemical catalysis.
Bingfang Shi is an associate professor in Baise University. He received his Ph.D. degree from Guangxi Normal University in 2016. His research interests include synthesis of nanomaterials, optical sensor and biological imaging.
Shulin Zhao is a professor. He received his B.S. degree in Analytical Chemistry from Hunan University, and Ph.D. degree in Chemical Engineering from Sichuan
University. Now, he works in Guangxi Normal University and majors in capillary electrophoresis, and chemical and biological sensing technology. He has published over 300 research papers.

sections.heading: Figure captions
sections.text:
Figure 1. Schematic illustration of the preparation of the N,P-GQDs (a). TEM image of the N,P-GQDs230°C, inset: particle size distribution (b). HRTEM image of the N,P-GQDs230°C, inset: 2D FFT pattern (c). AFM image of the N,P-GQDs230°C, inset: height profile (d).
Figure 2. HRTEM images (left) and corresponding 2D FFT patterns (right) of the N,P-GQDs250°C (a–e).
Figure 3. Survey XPS spectra of the N,P-GQDs230°C and the N,P-GQDs250°C.
Figure 4. Fluorescence and UV-vis absorption spectra of the N,P-GQDs230°C (a). Inset: photograph of the N,P-GQDs230°C solution under irradiation with natural light (left) and UV light (365 nm) (right). Emission spectra of the N,P-GQDs250°C (0.45 mg/mL) at different excitation wavelengths (b).
Figure 5. Fluorescence intensity ratio (I/I0) of the N,P-GQDs in the presence of different anions (the concentration of anions was 10 μM).
Figure 6. Fluorescence emission spectra of the N,P-GQDs230°C in the presence of NO2 -
(0.0–0.8 μM) (a). Dependence of the fluorescence quenching efficiency on the concentration of NO2 - (0.0–0.8 μM), inset: the linear relationship between the fluorescence quenching efficiency and NO2 - concentration (b).
Figure 7. Confocal fluorescence images of live T24 cells incubated with N,P-GQDs250°C for 20 h at 37 °C, with excitation wavelengths of 405 nm (a), 488 nm (b), 535 nm (c), overlap field (d, e), and bright field (f). Arrows indicate cell membrane. Scale bar = 20 μm.
Figure 8. Confocal fluorescence images in human bladder carcinoma T24 cells. Fluorescence mode (a–d) and bright-field (e–h) images of T24 cells treated with N,P-GQDs230°C and NO2 - (0, 10, 20, and 30 nM, respectively). (i) Normalized average PL intensities in a−d. λex=405 nm. Scale bar=20 μm.

A surface modifier onto the semiconductor surface may induce the lifetime of semiconductor colloids decreases [47].

When NO2 - is added into N,P-GQDs solution, the stronger interreaction of NO2 - with -NH2 on the surface of N,P-GQDs230°C result in electron transfer from the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) levels of N,P-GQDs to the of NO2 , which lead to fluorescence quenching [48].

A plausible reason for this phenomenon could be that the oxygen-rich N,P-GQDs230°C with a higher doping ratio of N and P contained more active sites [3], which can interact powerfully with NO2 - to strengthen nonradiative electron transfer.
